facts.text: Petition No. 104 of 1957 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 104 of 1957. Petition under Article 32 of the Constitution for the enforcement of fundamental rights.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 24, 1958 by Das C.J., Venkatarama Aiyar, S.K. Das and Sarkar JJ., with Bose J. separate judgment

anchor.surface_text: 1958. March 24. The Judgment of Das C. J. Venkatarama Aiyar, S. K. Das and Sarkar JJ. was delivered by Das C. J. Bose J. delivered a separate Judgment.

facts.text: Petitioner prays to set aside order made by respondent No. 3 on March 19, 1956 directing petitioner to stop cutting forest wood

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner has companye up before us on an application under Art. 32 of the Constitution praying for setting aside the order made by the respondent No. 3 on March 19, 1956, directing the petitioner to stop the cutting of forest wood

facts.text: Petitioner claims infringement of fundamental rights under Article 19(1)(f) and 19(1)(g)

anchor.surface_text: Since the application is under Art. 32 of the Constitution, the petitioner must make out that there has been an infringement of some fundamental right claimed by her. The petitioners grievance is that the offending order has infringed her fundamental right under Art. 19 1  f  and 19 1  g .

facts.text: Petitioner derived rights from document dated April 26, 1948 granted by husband Shri Balirambhau Doye

anchor.surface_text: She claims to have derived the fundamental rights, which are alleged to have been infringed, from a document dated April 26, 1948, whereby her husband Shri Balirambhau Doye, the proprietor of certain forests in eight several Tehsils, granted to her the right to take and appropriate all kinds of wood-Building wood, fuel wood and bamboos, etc.-from the said forests

facts.text: Document grants rights from April 26, 1948 to December 26, 1960 for Rs. 26,000

anchor.surface_text: for a period from the date of the document up to December 26, 1960. The petitioner has paid Rs. 26,000 as companysideration for the rights granted to her.

facts.text: Genuineness of document and good faith of parties not questioned

anchor.surface_text: The genuineness of this document and the good faith of the parties thereto have number been questioned.

facts.text: Document not registered under Indian Registration Act

anchor.surface_text: The document, however, has number been registered under the Indian Registration Act.

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights (Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands) Act, 1950 vested proprietary rights in State under s.3

anchor.surface_text: even then that right has vested in the State under s. 3 of the Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights  Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands  Act, 1950

facts.text: Act came into force on January 26, 1951

anchor.surface_text: In that year the Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights  Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands  Act, 1950, which came into force on January 26, 1951, was enacted.

facts.text: Vesting date for the area was March 31, 1951

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 3 of that Act, all proprietary rights in the land vest in the State on and from the date fixed in a numberification issued under sub-s.  1 . The date fixed for the vesting in this area was March 31, 1951.

facts.text: Petitioner worked the forests till 1950

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner says that she worked the forests till 1950.

facts.text: After vesting, petitioner stopped from cutting trees

anchor.surface_text: After that, the petitioner was stopped from cutting any more trees.

facts.text: Petitioner applied to Deputy Commissioner, Bhandara under s.6 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: She therefore applied to the Deputy Commissioner, Bhandara, under s. 6 2  of the Act for validating the lease.

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner held on August 16, 1955 that s.6 does not apply as transfer dated April 26, 1948 before March 16, 1950, but lease genuine and allowed to work forests

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Commissioner held, on August 16, 1955, that the section did number apply because it only applied to transfers made after March 16, 1950, whereas the petitioners transfer was made on April 26, 1948. But, despite that, he went on to hold that the Act did number apply to transfers made before March 16, 1950, and so leases before that companyld number be questioned. He also held that the lease was genuine and ordered that the petitioner be allowed to work the forests

facts.text: Petitioner claimed compensation from 1951-1955 but gave up on understanding allowed to work remaining period per DC order

anchor.surface_text: It seems that the petitioner claimed companypensation from Government for being ousted from the forests from 1951 to 1955 but gave up the claim on the understanding that she would be allowed to work the forests for the remaining period of the term in accordance with the Deputy Commissioners order dated August 16, 1955.

facts.text: Petitioner applied twice to Divisional Forest Officer at Bhandara for permission

anchor.surface_text: She thereupon went to the Divisional Forest Officer at Bhandara and asked for permission to work the forests in accordance with the above order. She applied twice

facts.text: Petitioner entered forests and started cutting trees (as alleged by Divisional Forest Officer)

anchor.surface_text: and, as all the companyfort she got was a letter saying that her claim was being examined, she seems to have taken the law into her own hands, entered the forests and started cutting the trees or so the Divisional Forest Officer says.

facts.text: Divisional Forest Officer on March 19, 1956 directed cancellation of name and forfeiture of cut materials

anchor.surface_text: The Divisional Forest Officer thereupon took action against her for unlawful cutting and directed that her name be cancelled and that the cut materials be forfeited. This was on March 19, 1956.

facts.text: Petitioner made application to Government of Madhya Pradesh on September 27, 1956

anchor.surface_text: Because of this, the petitioner went up to the Government of Madhya Pradesh and made an application dated September 27, 1956, asking that the Divisional Forest Officer be directed to give the petitioner immediate possession

facts.text: Petition to Supreme Court under Art. 32 on August 26, 1957

anchor.surface_text: Then, as numberhing tangible happened, she made a petition to this Court under Art. 32 of the Constitution on August 26, 1957.

facts.text: Petitioner's husband Balirambhau Doye was Zamindar of Pandharpur

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners husband, Balirambhau Doye, was the Zamindar of Pandharpur.

facts.text: Document executed by husband in favour of petitioner on April 26, 1948, unregistered, called itself a lease

anchor.surface_text: On April 26, 1948, he executed an unregistered document, that called itself a lease, in favour of his wife, the petitioner.

facts.text: Nature of document contested: contract, transfer, licence coupled with grant, relating to movable or immovable property

anchor.surface_text: The exact nature of this document was much canvassed before us in the arguments by both sides. It was said at various times by one side or the other to be a companytract companyferring companytractual rights, a transfer, a licence companypled with a grant, that it related to move able property and that, companytra, it related to immoveable property.

facts.text: Court dismissed the petition

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, agree that this petition should be dismissed with companyts.
Article 32 of the Constitution for the enforcement of fundamental rights.

concepts.interpretation: Petition under Article 32 for enforcement of fundamental rights requires proof of infringement of a fundamental right.

issues.text: Whether there has been an infringement of some fundamental right under Art. 19(1)(f) and 19(1)(g) claimed by the petitioner

anchor.surface_text: Art. 32 of the Constitution, the petitioner must make out that there has been an infringement of some fundamental right The petitioners grievance is that the offending order has infringed her fundamental right under Art. 19 1  f  and 19 1  g .

issues.text: What is the nature of the rights claimed by the petitioner under the document dated April 26, 1948

anchor.surface_text: The nature of the rights claimed by the petitioner has to be ascertained on a proper interpretation of the aforesaid document. We do not consider it necessary to examine or analyse the document minutely or to finally determine what we may regard as the true meaning and effect thereof,

issues.text: Whether the document confers any proprietary rights or interest on the petitioner

anchor.surface_text: I will examine the seventh clause first. The question is whether it confers any proprietary rights or interest on the petitioner. I do not think it does. It is clumsily worded but I think that the real meaning is this.

issues.text: Whether the right under the document is a profit-a-prendre or licence coupled with a grant amounting to an interest in immovable property

anchor.surface_text: if the document is construed as a license coupled with a grant, then the right acquired by her would be either in the nature of some profits-a-prendre which, being an interest in land, is immoveable property or a purely personal right under a contract.

issues.text: Whether the rights under the document have vested in the State under s. 3 of the Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights (Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands) Act, 1950

anchor.surface_text: even then that right has vested in the State under s. 3 of the Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights  Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands  Act, 1950 if the document is construed as purely a license granted to her to enter upon the land, then that license must be taken to have become extinguished

issues.text: Whether the document requires registration under the Indian Registration Act as it affects immovable property

anchor.surface_text: The document, however, has not been registered under the Indian Registration Act. The nature of the rights claimed by the petitioner has to be ascertained on a proper interpretation of the aforesaid document. ... the document does not affect the immoveable property

issues.text: Whether a contractual right under the document constitutes property under Arts. 19(1)(f) or 31(1) infringed by the State

anchor.surface_text: If, therefore, the document is construed as a matter of contract, then assuming but without deciding that a contract is a property within Arts. 19 1  f  or 31 1  of the Constitution, she cannot complain,

issues.text: Whether the grant relates to standing timber (movable property) or trees/immovable property

anchor.surface_text: If the petitioners rights are not more than the right to obtain future goods under the Sale of Goods Act, ... the question turns on whether this is a grant of moveable or immovable property. ... the Transfer of Property Act says in s. 3 that standing timber is not immoveable property

issues.text: Which definition of immovable property prevails: s. 3(26) General Clauses Act, s. 3 Transfer of Property Act or s. 2(6) Registration Act

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 3  26  of the General Clauses Act, it would be regarded as immovable property ... the Transfer of Property Act says in s. 3 that standing timber is not immoveable property for the purposes of that Act and so does s. 2  6  of the Registration Act. The question is which of these two definitions is to prevail.

issues.answer: General Clauses Act applies except for specific exclusions like standing timber

anchor.surface_text: I will examine the seventh clause first. The question is whether it confers any proprietary rights or interest on the petitioner. I do not think it does.

holdings.text: Whatever construction be put on the document dated April 26, 1948, the petitioner cannot complain of the breach of any of her fundamental rights under Articles 19(1)(f) and 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: We do not consider it necessary to examine or analyse the document minutely or to finally determine what we may regard as the true meaning and effect thereof, for, as will be presently seen, whatever construction be put on this document, the petitioner cannot complain of the breach of any of her fundamental rights.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exhaustive analysis of all possible constructions of the document shows no enforceable fundamental right survives against the State.

holdings.text: An unregistered document purporting to convey a part or share in proprietary rights does not affect immovable property or create any interest therein.

anchor.surface_text: If the document is construed as conveying to her any part or share in the proprietary right of the grantor, then, not being registered under the Indian Registration Act, the document does not affect the immoveable property or give her any right to any share or interest in the immoveable property.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Indian Registration Act requires registration for documents affecting immovable property; non-registration renders ineffective.

holdings.text: Any proprietary right acquired under the document vested in the State under section 3 of the Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Assuming that she had acquired a share or interest in the proprietary right in spite of the document not having been registered, even then that right has vested in the State under s. 3 of the Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights  Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands  Act, 1950

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proprietary rights vest absolutely in State on notified date regardless of prior alienations unless validated.

holdings.text: A pure license to enter upon the land is extinguished upon vesting of proprietary rights in the State under section 3 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: If the document is construed as purely a license granted to her to enter upon the land, then that license must be taken to have become extinguished as soon as the grantors proprietary rights in the land vested in the State under s. 3 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Licenses depend on licensor's title; vesting extinguishes.

holdings.text: A profit Ã  prendre being an interest in immovable property requires registration; unregistered document ineffective to create it.

anchor.surface_text: if the document is construed as a license coupled with a grant, then the right acquired by her would be either in the nature of some profits-a-prendre which, being an interest in land, is immoveable property ... as has been held in Ananda Behera The State of Orissa  1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Profit Ã  prendre is interest in land per precedent; Registration Act applies.

holdings.text: A purely contractual right, even if property under Articles 19(1)(f) or 31(1), is not infringed by State not being party to the contract.

anchor.surface_text: If, therefore, the document is construed as a matter of contract, then assuming but without deciding that a contract is a property within Arts. 19 1  f  or 31 1  of the Constitution, she cannot complain, for the State has not acquired or taken possession of her contract in any way.

holdings.reasoning_summary: State not bound by private contract; remedy is suit for damages, not writ.

holdings.text: The petition should be dismissed with costs as no fundamental right infringed.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, agree that this petition should be dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of above; Art.32 requires infringement of fundamental right.

holdings.text: The document does not confer any proprietary rights or interest on the petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether it confers any proprietary rights or interest on the petitioner. I do not think it does. It is clumsily worded but I think that the real meaning is this.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of clause 7 shows no transfer; merely managerial role recitation.

holdings.text: The document confers only a right to enter lands to cut certain trees and carry away wood, i.e., licence coupled with grant or profit Ã  prendre.

anchor.surface_text: In my opinion, the document only confers a right to enter on the lands in order to cut down certain kinds of trees and carry away the wood. To that extent the matter is covered by the decision in Chhotabhai Jethabhai Patel Co. v. The State of Madhya Pradesh  1 ,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not lease of land but right to take produce; follows precedents Chhotabhai and Ananda Behera.

holdings.text: Petitioner has no fundamental right to cut and collect timber; follows Ananda Behera (5 judges) over Chhotabai (3 judges).

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given in Ananda Beheras case  1 , I would hold that she has none. This runs counter to Chhotebhai Jethabhai Patels case but, as that was a decision of three Judges and the other five,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Larger bench precedent binds; profit Ã  prendre not fundamental property right.

holdings.text: Pure contractual right simpliciter does not constitute fundamental right under Articles 19(1)(f) or 31(1) against non-party State.

anchor.surface_text: As a matter of fact, the rights in the earlier case were held to flow from a licence and not from a contract simpliciter see page 483 but it is true that the learned Judges held that a writ petition lay.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Personal contractual rights not property for constitutional protection; breach is contractual, not constitutional.

holdings.text: Right to enter land and cut/carry timber is a benefit arising out of land, immovable property under General Clauses Act s.3(26).

anchor.surface_text: Following the decision in Ananda Beheras case  1 , I would hold that a right to enter on land for the purpose of cutting and carrying away timber standing on it is a benefit that arises out of land.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies definition; no difference between English/Indian law.

holdings.text: Trees attached to earth (except standing timber) are immovable property; General Clauses s.3(26) applies absent specific exclusion.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 3  26  of the General Clauses Act, it would be regarded as immovable property because it is a benefit that arises out of the land and also because trees are attached to the earth.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonizes definitions; specific Acts exclude standing timber but not other trees.

holdings.text: Standing timber means trees fit for building etc., intended to be cut soon such that nourishment from soil negligible.

anchor.surface_text: Timber is well enough known to be- wood suitable for building houses, bridges, ships etc., whether on the tree or cut and seasoned. Therefore, standing timber must be a tree that is in a state fit for these purposes

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive definition based on dictionary, forestry practice, nourishment test; distinguishes from ordinary trees.

holdings.text: The document covers not only standing timber but trees requiring further growth/nourishment over 12 years, hence immovable property requiring registration.

anchor.surface_text: Now, how does the document in question regard this In the first place, the duration of the grant is twelve years. It is evident that trees that will be fit for cutting twelve years hence will not be fit for felling now.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual: long term, girth restrictions, multiple cuttings indicate benefit from soil growth.

precedents.citation: Ananda Behera The State of Orissa 1

anchor.surface_text: Ananda Behera The State of Orissa 1

precedents.case_name: Ananda Behera v. State of Orissa
